repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fix #23231

`vim.ui.os_open` is partially based off https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim/blob/main/lua/lazy/util.lua#L13-L44, as recommended by @folke on the original issue.

- [x] Implement `vim.ui.os_open(uri: string | vim.uri.Uri)`
    - [x] Accept a `string` as `uri`
    - [ ] ~~Accept a `vim.uri.Uri` as `uri`~~
- [x] Implement "gx" in lua. The implementation drops current netrw options, including `g:netrw_gx`.
- [ ] Ability to change impl by using `vim.func.on_func(vim.ui, 'open_uri', â€¦)`

comment_data.body:
there should use system to check . not check executable .  like 
```lua
local ismac  = vim.loop.os_uname().sysname == 'Darwin'
-- windows check also like ismac.

if ismac then
     cmd = 'open'
end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,4 +104,40 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm) end end +--- Opens a URI by sending it to the system's default handler +--- Uses `xdg-open`, `wslview`, and `open` depending on the operating system to +--- attempt to open the URI +--- +--- +---@param uri string Uri to be opened +--- TODO: uri should accept vim.uri.Uri +--- +--- Example: +--- 
lua
+--- vim.ui.input("https://neovim.io/")
+---
+--- vim.ui.input("/path/to/file")
+---
+function M.open_uri(uri) + local cmd + + if vim.fn.executable('xdg-open') == 1 then + cmd = { 'xdg-open', uri } + elseif vim.fn.executable('wslview') == 1 then + cmd = { 'wslview', uri } + else

comment_data.body:
and you can just run `vim.loop.os_uname().sysname` this once right 
 ```lua
  local sysname = vim.loop.os_uname().sysname
  if sysname == 'Darwin' then
        open 
  elseif sysname:match('Windows') then
        foo
  else 
       bar 
  end
  ```

comment_data.body:
Could this return the `ret` and maybe have a second `opts` parameter with `quiet` to surpress the message? Then it could be used in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/02d5a678fbf4ed36b4896010a051f136d587e779/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/handlers.lua#L571-L580

I'm not sure about the opts/quiet, maybe it's fine to always have the error notification.

`system()` and `jobstart()` will complain either way.

comment_data.body:
I'd leave this out of this PR as it is a behavior change for LSP and it's not clear to me that having this confirm dialog is an improvement.

And it also seems to me that there's no good reason to build  this check into `open_uri` instead of doing it outside.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,4 +104,66 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm) end end +--- Opens a URI by sending it to the system's default handler. +--- This function utilizes `xdg-open`, `wslview`, or `open` commands depending on +--- the operating system to open the provided URI. +--- +--- +---@param uri string Uri to be opened +--- +---@param opts table|nil Optional keyword arguments: +--- - confirm boolean|nil Ask user for confirmation before opening. +--- +---@return string|nil returns the string output of the command. nil if +---opts.confirm and the user declined. See |system()|. +--- +--- Example: +--- 
lua
+--- vim.ui.open_uri("https://neovim.io/")
+---
+--- vim.ui.open_uri("/path/to/file")
+---
+function M.open_uri(uri, opts) + vim.validate({ + opts = { opts, 'table', true }, + }) + + opts = opts or {} + local cmd + local sysname = vim.loop.os_uname().sysname + + if sysname == 'Darwin' then + cmd = 'open' + elseif sysname:match('windows') then + cmd = 'wslview' + else -- Assume linux + cmd = 'xdg-open' + end + + if opts.confirm then + local answer = + vim.fn.confirm('Open "' .. uri .. '" using ' .. cmd .. '?', '&Yes\n&No', 2, 'Question') + + if answer == 0 or answer == 2 then + return + end + end

comment_data.body: Should still check executable(xdg-open) as in https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim/blob/6610b15dfd76f7992423916e2b87f031881d7b25/lua/lazy/util.lua#L13-L44 , else user could see a confusing error.

See |system()|. +--- +--- Example: +---

comment_data.body: @clason I think we can make this opt-out rather than opt-in from the start, it's low risk.

     vim.treesitter.inspect_tree()
   end

+
+if vim.g.use_lua_gx ~= nil then

comment_data.body: The purpose is to avoid netrw so supporting `vim.g.netrw_gx` is out of scope. For now we can just use `<cfile>`, eventually we might want to introduce `<curi>`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -18,3 +18,11 @@ vim.api.nvim_create_user_command('InspectTree', function(cmd)
     vim.treesitter.inspect_tree()
   end
 end, { desc = 'Inspect treesitter language tree for buffer', count = true })
+
+if vim.g.use_lua_gx ~= nil then
+  vim.keymap.set({ 'n', 'x' }, 'gx', function()
+    local uri = vim.fn.expand(vim.g.netrw_gx ~= nil and vim.g.netrw_gx or '<cfile>')

comment_data.body:
Perhaps we should just name it `vim.ui.open`, mentioning "URI" in the name is perhaps confusing because it also supported non-URI filesystem names. 

Opening stuff in the editor (Nvim) is called "edit" rather than "open" so that hopefully is enough distinction.

Other ideas: `os_open`, `open_external` ?

See |system()|. +--- +--- Example: +--- 
lua

+---

+---
+function M.open_uri(uri)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
â€¢ |vim.ui.open_uri()| opens URIs using the system default handler (macOS `open`, Windows Explorer, Linux `xdg-open`, etc.) 
```

comment_data.body:
Better to use `jobstart` here. `vim.fn.system` sometimes fails for unknown reasons. See here for example https://github.com/folke/lazy.nvim/issues/18

```lua
  local ret = vim.fn.jobstart(cmd, { detach = true })
  if ret <= 0 then
    local msg = {
      "Failed to open uri",
      ret,
      vim.inspect(cmd),
    }
    vim.notify(table.concat(msg, "\n"), vim.log.levels.ERROR)
  end
```

comment_data.body: I cannot find much of a reason to prefer explorer. `start` might even be better since it can provide better filetype-handler errors where as `explorer` will just fail silently and open in the file explorer in a random default location. (I think)

@@ -104,4 +104,49 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm) end end +--- Opens a URI by sending it to the system's default handler. +--- This function utilizes `xdg-open`, `wslview` / `start`, or `open` commands +--- depending on the system to open the provided URI. +--- +--- +---@param uri string Uri to be opened +--- +---@return string returns the string output of the command. See |system()|. +--- +--- Example: +--- 
lua
+--- vim.ui.open_uri("https://neovim.io/")
+---
+--- vim.ui.open_uri("/path/to/file")
+---
+function M.open_uri(uri) + local cmd + + if vim.fn.has("wsl") then + cmd = "wslview" + elseif vim.fn.has("mac") then + cmd = 'open' + elseif vim.fn.has("win32") then + cmd = "start" + else -- Assume linux + cmd = 'xdg-open'

comment_data.body: If you're very keen on using `start` you could try to pass `cmd` + `path` as a joined string rather than a table I suppose. (`:help jobstart()` for full details)

See |system()|. +--- +--- Example: +---

```suggestion
    detach = true,

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -104,4 +104,57 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm) end end +--- Opens a path in the system's default handler. +--- This function utilizes `xdg-open`, `wslview`, `start`, or `open` commands +--- depending on the system to open the provided path. +--- +--- +---@param path string Path to be opened +--- +---@return number returns the job id of the command. See |job-id|. +--- +--- Example: +--- 
lua
+--- vim.ui.os_open("https://neovim.io/")
+---
+--- vim.ui.os_open("/path/to/file")
+---
+function M.os_open(path) + local cmd + + if vim.fn.has('macunix') == 1 then + cmd = { 'open', path } + elseif vim.fn.has('win32') == 1 then + cmd = { 'cmd', '/C', 'start', path } + else + if vim.fn.executable('xdg-open') == 1 then + cmd = { 'xdg-open', path } + elseif vim.fn.executable('wslview') == 1 then + cmd = { 'wslview', path } + else + vim.notify( + 'os_open: Could not find an appropriate command to use (Is xdg-open installed?)', + vim.log.levels.ERROR + ) + + return -1 + end + end + + local ret = vim.fn.jobstart(cmd, { + detatch = true,

comment_data.body: After more thought, I'm pretty certain that `vim.ui.open` is good. There could be `vim.fs.open` also, but they're in separate namespaces and the purpose is clear: "fs" is for filesystem, "ui" is where platform-specific providers live.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2211,6 +2211,24 @@ input({opts}, {on_confirm})                                   *vim.ui.input()*
                       typed (it might be an empty string if nothing was
                       entered), or `nil` if the user aborted the dialog.
 
+os_open({path})                                             *vim.ui.os_open()*

comment_data.body:

open({path})                                             *vim.ui.open()*
```

comment_regular_data.body: the `uri` need check include some symbols or not ,  like `#` .  in some lsp hover response the link like `file:///usr/local/share/doc/xxx/System-IO.html#v:putStrLn` .  so you need use `vim.fn.escape` to escape `#` in uri .

> Is deleting code from runtime/plugin/netrwPlugin.vim appropriate / allowed?

No, please leave it as is (for now). It's better to set the corresponding global variables to skip setting up the mapping.

We'll completely remove netrw once we have a full replacement.

> What is the correct way to add new built-in keymaps in lua? The best location I found was runtime/plugin/nvim.lua.

Yes, that would be the place. But maybe make it opt-in for now?
God, the commit history in this PR is a complete mess lmao

> No, please leave it as is (for now). It's better to set the corresponding global variables to skip setting up the mapping.

I am confused about the execution order, where would you set a global variable in time? I cannot find a place where this is done

> the uri need check include some symbols or not , like # . in some lsp hover response the link like file:///usr/local/share/doc/xxx/System-IO.html#v:putStrLn . so you need use vim.fn.escape to escape # in uri .

Im not entirely sure what you mean. Most applications will not understand what `#v:putStrLn` means. You can try to maybe adjust `g:netrw_gx` to capture the full #? (as `<cfile>` rightfully does not expect a file to have #)

it's a markdown link return by some lsp server. it has a `#` target symbol . but maybe it should not escape in `open_uri` function.  if I want use `open_uri` to open it i need escape `#` symbol by myself :)

> I am confused about the execution order, where would you set a global variable in time? I cannot find a place where this is done

In your `init.vim`.  The point is only to add the functionality for now so users can use that instead of `netRW` _if they choose_. In a second step (after the early access crowd has found the majority of bugs), we can make this the default.
This would be a lot easier if i had a windows machine to test it on.

pushed an update : 

- fix for visual `gx`
- test coverage
- buggy condition in lsp handler

I do hate `explorer` but `start` is somehow worse. currently with `explorer` on windows `vim.ui.open("google.com")` will open the file manager at some random location without warning.

But `start` requires a bunch of weird stuff. start for some reason interprets the first argument as the title, but not always(?). start also is entirely different depending on the shell and has some strangeness with spaces, which explorer properly handles.

> currently with `explorer` on windows `vim.ui.open("google.com")` will open the file manager at some random location without warning.

without "https://" that would be treated as a filepath on any system, afaik. 

If you find that netrw's `gx` on Windows works better, we could use its `start rundll32 url.dll,FileProtocolHandler` approach: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3ecd45ded044c47efa76b74e9e3b720fbe27adc7/runtime/autoload/netrw.vim#L5431-L5433

I should be able to not load netrw plugin completely after this, shouldn't I?

```lua
vim.g.loaded_netrwPlugin = 1
vim.g.loaded_netrw = 1
```

`gx` errors me with:
```
E117: Unknown function: netrw#GX
E116: Invalid arguments for function netrw#BrowseX
```

Thanks.
Cannot reproduce

Got it. I don't know why, but the netrw plugin `share/nvim/runtime/plugin/netrwPlugin.vim` is being loaded before the `init.lua`file (where I tell nvim to not load netrw through the `vim.g.loaded_netrwPlugin` global var). ðŸ¤·ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ Maybe there is some other issue there, or even some misconfiguration on my side.

> the netrw plugin `share/nvim/runtime/plugin/netrwPlugin.vim` is being loaded before the `init.lua`file (where I tell nvim to not load netrw through the `vim.g.loaded_netrwPlugin` global var)

May need to revert https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24262 , or move this mapping to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/06c4edf46bf65ec6b540de355cf1a691533f1df9/runtime/lua/vim/_editor.lua#L1008

@justinmk On Windows this call fails: ``` lua vim.ui.open('https://devdocs.io/#q=lua%20lua_call') ``` I think that the reason is that Explorer doesn't accept the URL: The message says the its an invalid URL but its a valid one for devdocs. Is there any alternative to avoid this dependency?

> I think that the reason is that Explorer doesn't accept the URL ...  Is there any alternative to avoid this dependency?

See above, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1621187483 . Patch welcome, having someone with a Windows machine would be helpful.
maybe it's worth switching the opener strategy on windows
is that different than what i said in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1621187483 ?

> is that different than what i said in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1621187483 ?

It's the same issue.
